question: A 45-year-old woman has had a severe headache with nausea and vomiting for the past 2 days. On physical examination her blood pressure is 290/160 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show her serum creatinine is 3.7 mg/dL. The representative microscopic appearance of her kidneys is depicted here. Which of the following underlying diseases is she most likely to have? <image 1>
description: The image depicts a histological section of kidney tissue under a microscope. The tissue shows characteristic features of arteriolosclerosis, which is a thickening and hyalinization of the walls of small arteries and arterioles. This condition is often associated with chronic hypertension and long-standing diabetes mellitus. The vessels appear to have a concentric, onion-skin-like pattern of thickening, which is typical of malignant hypertension or severe diabetic nephropathy. The surrounding tissue also shows signs of fibrosis and scarring, indicating chronic damage.
